text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
GAZETA MERCANTIL
-- SOME $3.6 BLN TO FLOW INTO BRAZIL THROUGH JUNE

Brazil will draw about $3.6 billion in dollar flows from foreign investment over the next two months, including $1.6 billion from the privatization of mining concern CVRD and from a $1.2 billion share offering by retail bank Unibanco next week in the United States, according to Central Bank international affairs director Gustavo Franco.
-- CENTRAL BANK INVESTIGATES INTERNAL FRAUD
The Central Bank said it was investigating two employees on its gold trading desk and a foreign financial institution. Activities under investigation took place in 1995-96.
-- PROER OFFERS 20.8 BLN REAIS IN CREDIT TO BANKS

Making some 20.8 billion reais in credit available to banks under the program to encourage mergers and acquisitions, known as Proer, has cost the governemnt 660 million reais. The money was loaned to banks between October 1995 and March 1997.
O GLOBO
-- PMDB, OPPOSITION BRING REFORMS TO IMPASSE

Opposition parties and the PMDB, angered by a government attempt to avoid voting on a number of controversial amendments to its civil service reform bill and by questions over cabinet nominations, brought progress on the reform bill to a halt.
-- NEW CVRD OWNER STEINBRUCH OPEN TO JAPANESE PARTNERS

New CVRD owner Benjamin Steinbruch said he was open to forming partnerships with Japanese firms and others who are interested. He said CVRD officials will travel to Japan and Australia to meet with potential partners.
FOLHA DE SAO PAULO
-- COURT INJUNCTION STILL BLOCKS TRANSFER OF CVRD SHARES
The CSN-led consortia may pay 3.3 billion reais for CVRD, but company shares won't trade hands until an injunction is overturned in the courts.
-- INFLATION IN SAO PAULO AT 0.64 PCT IN APRIL
Sao Paulo inflation measured by the Economic Institute (Fipe) was 0.64 pct in April, up from 0.21 percent in March.
-- Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
((-- John Miller, Sao Paulo Newsroom 5511-248-5414))
